entry.title: Avoiding RFC Timeout Issues During SAP Table Job Extraction in SAP Data Services
entry.content:
Avoiding RFC Timeouts: Executing SAP Table Extractions Jobs in Background via RFC Batch 

Introduction

Extracting large volumes of data from SAP systems using SAP Data Services (BODS) can be a real challenge ‚Äî especially when working with standard (non-ABAP) dataflows. One of the most common issues encountered is the dreaded RFC timeout, which occurs when a data extraction takes too long to return results, and the SAP session times out.

In many environments, using ABAP dataflows to offload processing to SAP is restricted due to governance or lack of ABAP resources. So, how can we extract large datasets without ABAP Dataflow, and still avoid timeouts?

In this blog, we explore how executing jobs in RFC batch background mode can help solve this problem.

Understanding RFC Timeouts

An RFC (Remote Function Call) allows SAP Data Services to call SAP functions like  RFC_READ_TABLE to extract data. However, when these calls are executed in dialog mode (default), they inherit the standard timeout settings of an interactive SAP user session ‚Äî typically 600 to 1800 seconds (10‚Äì30 minutes).

When a query takes too long ‚Äî due to high data volume, slow performance, or unfiltered extraction ‚Äî the RFC session times out, causing the job to fail.

What Is "Execute in Background Job in RFC Batch"?

"Execute in background job in RFC batch" means:

  • The RFC-connected extraction is not executed in foreground (interactive user session).

  • Instead, SAP submits the job to the background job scheduler, and the logic is run as a batch job.

  • This background job is still triggered via RFC but runs asynchronously, bypassing timeout limitations.

 

Benefits of Executing in RFC Batch Background

  • Avoids dialog session timeouts

  • Allows longer-running data extraction jobs

  • Reduces job failures in SAP Data Services

  • No need for ABAP code or ABAP dataflows

 

Steps to Enable Background Job Execution for SAP Table Extraction

  1. Double-click on the SAP Table:

    • In SAP Data Services Designer, double-click on the SAP table you want to extract (for example, EKKO) to open its properties.

       

  2. Open Source Table Editor:

    • This opens the Source Table Editor options for that table.

  3. Enable Background Execution:

    • In the Source Table Editor, locate and enable the option Execute in Background (Batch) .

       

       

  4. Save the Job:

    • Save your changes to the dataflow or job.

  5. Run the Job:

    • Execute the job. The extraction will now run as a background RFC batch job, preventing timeout errors typical of foreground execution.

entry.title: How to use Run_Batch_Job web services call?
entry.content:
Before proceeding, check the documentation below:

  • Using SAP Data Services as a SOAP Web Service provider | SAP Help Portal

Let's use SoapUI as a third-party trigger for our job without the need of exposing the Job directly, but before using the Run_Batch_Job operation, it is important to check if our Session Security is enabled from Data Services Management Console (DSMC).

From DSMC, access the Administrator tab, go to "Web Services" and  "Web Services Configuration".

If Session Security is enabled, you must perform a Logon operation to get a Session ID to provide to the Run_Batch_Job web service call, also perform the Logout to close that session.
Session Security is enabled by default and we will be using it during this post.

On DSMC, let's select "View WSDL" from Web Services Status tab:

It will open a new browser tab, showing the WSDL xml file:

Copy the URL to use on SoapUI. In my case, this is my URL:

  • http://localhost:8080/DataServices/servlet/webservices?ver=2.1&wsdlxml

Since I will be testing from SoapUI installed on the same machine as the web tier application, I will be using localhost, but it would be the SERVER NAME / HOST instead of "localhost".

From SoapUI, right-click on Projects and select "New SOAP Project":

 

Give a name to your project and provide the URL previously collected on DSMC. Click "OK":

It will provide all the Operations available on the WSDL:

We will be using three operations for this test: Logon, Run_Batch_Job and Logout.

Double-click under the request created during the project creation or create a new request, input the CMS information for the connection (same as your CMC login credentials) and execute the Request. 

Check: Logon | SAP Help Portal

You might face an error in case you need to use the cms_system port depending of the application version.
Refer to SAP Note: 3412752 - SAP Data Services Logon web service does not take port in the cms_system parameter.

Logon operation will return a Session ID as previously mentioned in this post:

Now, let's execute a request of Run_Batch_Job.
Check: Run_Batch_Job | SAP Help Portal

I will remove some sections (jobParameters and globalVariables) and the serverGroup parameter, since it does not apply for my test and we will reuse the SessionID from our Logon call:

It successfully ran:

From Data Services Management Console (DSMC) > Administrator > Status / Batch > Training_DS (This is your repository section) > Batch Job Status, you will be able to check the execution history:

After this execution, we will perform a Logout call.
Check: Logout | SAP Help Portal

Note: Tests and screenshots taken from SAP Data Services 2025 version.

Every Web Services call must work outside of SAP Data Services, and in this post, your learned how to applied on SoapUI.
For third party schedulers or tools that could be used to trigger our jobs, you must check with its provider what are the required information to proceed.

üåüIf you have any questions or need assistance, feel free to reach out to SAP Support and search under our Knowledge Base!

entry.title: Designer Installation: Step-by-Step Guide for SAP Data Services Client Tool üíª
entry.content:
Make sure you download Designer setup with the same version as your Data Services Job Server machine, which consequently makes the Designer certified with the CMS (BI/IPS) version.

In case you have BI/IPS application or client installed on this machine, make sure it is also certified with your Designer application, even if it is not being used as CMS Server:

  • 3322026- Can BOE/BI/IPS Platform Client Tools and Designer Client Tool coexist in the same machine? - SAP Data Services

Download Designer using the steps below:

  • Software Center - SAP for Me > SUPPORT PACKAGES & PATCHES > By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) > D > SAP DATA SERVICES > SAP DATA SERVICES 4.x > SAP DS CLIENT TOOLS 4.x > Select a compatible version and download it

NOTE: This post is using Designer Client 2025 (14.4.0.165) as screenshots reference.

INSTALLATION STEPS üöÄ

After downloading the setup, let's start the installation.

  1. Run the installer as Administrator user to avoid any problems.
  2. Make sure all the prerequisites which are Critical type are on Succeeded status and click on Next.

  3. Read and select the "I accept the License Agreement". Click on Next.



  4. Add the same valid License Key as your Data Services application server and click on Next:



    Additional content:
    1977090- Is a new license key required when upgrading to Data Services 4.2, 4.3 or 2025?

  5. Confirm the installation path and click on Next.



  6. Confirm the %DS_COMMON_DIR% directory of SAP Data Services Designer and click on Next:



  7. Select any additional language and click on Next:

  8. Select "Skip CMS", since this is the Designer Client tool installation and not the application server and click on Next:



  9. Uncheck the "Data Services Server" box and click on Next:



  10. Select "Skip Configuration", since this is your Designer client machine and the DSConfig.txt files will be under your Job Server machine. Click on Next.



  11. Start the installation. Click Next:



  12. Installation is complete. Click on Finish.



  13. Reboot machine is required. Only click on "Yes" after confirming that you can restart your machine right now.



  14. Your Designer should be accessible:

 

Additional content:

  • "The base keycode for the Data Services platform was not found or has expired. Obtain a valid keycode and use the License Manager to update your installation. (BODI-1116106)" after Designer installation / upgrade:

    Check the KBA below:
    1395080- How to install or maintain License/Product keys - SAP Data Services
  • For SAP Data Services 2025, missing ncs.dll:
    3641815 - Designer fails to launch with keycode error - SAP Data Services 2025

  • For SDK Failure when accessing Designer tool: 
    It might be compatibility between your Designer tool and the CMS Server (BI/IPS), but also bi-directionally communication between Designer <-> CMS Server.
    Make sure you can ping and telnet from Designer to the CMS Server and vice versa (CMS Server to Designer).
    In case it is compatible and telnet/ping works bi-directionally, check and apply the KBA below:

    2450650 - Logon failed to the specified system. Check system name, port number, user name, password, authentication method, and try again. Additional information: <Session: SDK failure>. - SAP Data Services
  • Designer client is slow:
    3034996- SAP Data Services Designer slow performance - SAP Data Services

 

üåüIf you have any questions or need assistance, feel free to reach out to SAP Support and search under our Knowledge Base!

entry.title: Can SAP‚Äôs Real-Time Analytics Redefine Decision-Making for the C-Suite?
entry.content:
The Changing Role of Leaders

Today‚Äôs CEOs and CTOs face more data than ever before. Numbers flow in from finance, supply chain, and customers. The challenge is not access. The challenge is speed. Leaders cannot wait days for reports. They need answers now.

Why Real-Time Matters

Traditional reporting works on past data. By the time insights reach the boardroom, the market may have moved. Real-time analytics flips this model. It brings live data from operations straight to decision-makers. A CEO can see global sales by region as they happen. A CTO can monitor system health before an outage hits.

How SAP Enables This

  • SAP HANA: stores and processes data in-memory for instant results.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): gives live dashboards and predictive models.
  • Embedded Analytics: in S/4HANA allows leaders to view insights while working inside core processes.

These tools cut delays and remove the guesswork.

Practical Example

Imagine a manufacturer facing a sudden raw material shortage. Without real-time analytics, the CEO learns of it after a weekly report. With SAP, alerts appear the moment supply drops. Leaders can adjust sourcing, update prices, and inform partners‚Äîall within hours, not days.

Best Practices for the C-Suite

  • Ask sharper questions: Real-time data works best when leaders know what to track.
  • Balance speed with accuracy: Not all data needs live updates. Focus on what drives action.
  • Build trust in data: If executives doubt the system, they will fall back on instinct.

Challenges to Watch

Real-time analytics is powerful, but not simple. Common issues include:

  • Integrating data from multiple systems.
  • Ensuring security and access control.
  • Training leaders to read dashboards, not just slides.

The Bigger Picture

Real-time analytics does not replace leadership. It sharpens it. CEOs still need vision. CTOs still need strategy. SAP‚Äôs role is to provide clear, trusted signals so leaders can act without delay.

Engage Further

The question for the C-suite is simple: Are you ready to let real-time data guide your next move? If you want to explore practical steps, connect with experts, or join discussions in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Use of DSEDIT tool to create entry in sql.ini file for Sybase ASE database
entry.content:
SAP Data Services installation stalls as the installer is unable to identify the CMS and Audit repositories.

Environment for this installation setup

  • Product - SAP Data Services 4.3 
  • Database - Sybase ASE 16.0
  • Operating system - Windows Server 2019 Standard

Initial investigation took us to the ODBC connections and it worked fine and successfully connected to the respective database repositories. However on deeper analysis, it was observed that for the backend Sybase ASE database the connection doesn‚Äôt utilizes the ODBC connectors, it requires a Sybase client to be installed on the application machine and the resulting sql.ini file needs to be updated with the entries for CMS and AUDIT repositories.

SAP Data Services or Business Intelligence installation on Sybase ASE database needs the following client to be installed on the application host

After the installation below shown "sql.ini" file is created which needs to be amended with the entries of the repositories required for connection.

 

The format for the entries are

[CMS]
master=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>
query=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>

[AUDIT]
master=<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>
query=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>

 

Another way of updating the sql.ini file is to use the DSEDIT tool provided by the client.

Launch the tool with administrator access

Click Ok

Click on the ServerObject and select Add

Enter the name of the repository, this should be exactly the same which will be used in the installation, in this example ‚ÄúCMS‚Äù

Double click on the server address bar on the right and click on the add button

On the TCP protocol in the network address bar enter the hostname/IP address followed by the port number at which the Sybase ASE DB is reachable separated by a comma

Once the entry is added test the connection

Right click and select Ping Server

Click on Ping

A connect succeeded message will prove the connection is successfully established, and an entry will get created in the sql.ini file with right syntax and parameters.

Now the installer will identify the CMS and AUDIT database repositories

entry.title: Hedonic Pricing: What Do Investors Pay For?
entry.content:
Executive summary
Investors do not primarily pay for short-term margin spikes or isolated growth initiatives.  Instead, over a 35-year horizon, the market has consistently rewarded one thing above all else: persistency.  This is the term Goldman Sachs attaches to the capital structure discipline, specifically leverage (Assets/Equity).  We find that leverage explains the majority of the variation in Home Depot‚Äôs Market Cap / Equity, our proxy for the Price/Book ratio.  This finding closely replicates Goldman Sachs‚Äô famous analysis of what markets pay for, but applies to a single company and validates using long-horizon time-series data. Profitability and efficiency matter ‚Äî but they come second.

This note describes our findings in three simple blocks:

  • data preparation and transformation
  • results and interpretation
  • what it means for Home Depot and investors.

 

1. Data preparation: looking at Home Depot the way markets do

This analysis starts from a simple premise:

If we want to understand how investors value Home Depot, we must model Home Depot the way investors observe it.

We assembled 144 quarters (1990‚Äì2025 YTD) of data covering both market valuation metrics (P/B ratio, Market Cap, Enterprise Value) and accounting fundamentals (assets, equity, leverage, margins, asset turnover).

This is important: unlike cross-sectional studies across many firms, this model is time-series for a single company. We are not asking why Home Depot is valued differently than Lowe‚Äôs.  We are asking a more precise question:

What has historically driven changes in Home Depot‚Äôs valuation over time?

Log transformations: elasticity, not levels

All core variables are expressed in logarithmic form. This is essential for interpretation:

  • Coefficients become elasticities
  • Relationships become scale-free
  • Long-term growth dynamics dominate short-term noise

In plain English: we are modeling percentage changes investors respond to, not absolute dollar movements.

The dependent (predicted) variable is the

ln(Market Cap / Equity), a proxy for the P/B ratio, directly links market valuation to balance-sheet fundamentals ‚Äî exactly how long-term equity investors think.

Three independent (predictor) variables are

Leverage = (Assets - Goodwill) / Stockholders Equity where we specifically remove Goodwill to account for ‚Äútangible leverage‚Äù only,

Net Margin = Net Income / Revenue, 

Turnover = Revenue / (Assets - Goodwill) here too, assets are net of goodwill for "tangible turnover."

In one quarter, Home Depot reported negative net income. In 9 quarters the company reported negative equity - initially in 2019 as a result of the adoption of the FASB ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases (Topic 842)".  This is why the lines in the plot below exhibit discontinuities: natural logarithm of a negative number is undefined.

In log terms, valuation and operating fundamentals move in clear and persistent co-movement over time.  Sustained multiple expansion coincides with rising operating efficiency, greater leverage capacity, and improving margins, while periods of valuation compression align with broad-based fundamental deterioration.  Valuation itself behaves as a slow-moving state variable, reflecting investors‚Äô long-run assessment of economic capacity, whereas operating metrics adjust at higher frequency around that state.  Even during externally imposed disruptions‚Äîsuch as recessions and market panics‚Äîtemporary dislocations give way to re-convergence, underscoring that market multiples are ultimately disciplined by fundamentals rather than driven by sentiment alone.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This systematic co-movement directly motivates a hedonic valuation, in which observed market multiples are modeled as the equilibrium price investors assign to distinct operating characteristics rather than as standalone time-series outcomes.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

2. The hedonic pricing regression: what explains Home Depot's valuation?

Conceptually, the model mirrors the DuPont identity, which decomposes Return on Equity into three elements:

  • Leverage (Assets / Equity)
  • Profitability (Net Margin)
  • Efficiency (Asset Turnover)

Our model - with the log-transformed data - is:

To accommodate periods of negative net margin and negative stockholders‚Äô equity, we introduced dummy variables that flag sign changes (0 for positive values, 1 for negative).  The inclusion of dummy variables allows the model to accommodate sign changes without materially altering coefficient magnitudes or inference. 

The regression, run in R Studio, produced a formula where most coefficients are statistically significant at the 5% level (p<0.05).  The ln_net_margin variable returned a p-value of 0.0744, indicating a 7.4% probability of observing this result (or one more extreme) if there were actually no relationship between ln_net_margin and ln_mktcap_over_equity.

We drop the decimals:

Here is the most intuitive interpretation of the model‚Äôs coefficients and log-terms: elasticity. These bars represent standardized coefficients, not raw elasticities, and are intended for relative magnitude and intuition, not literal percentage translation.


 

Home Depot‚Äôs valuation is most sensitive to changes in asset turnover, indicating that improvements in capital efficiency drive market multiples more powerfully than margin expansion alone.

In raw log terms, leverage can be interpreted as follows: a 1% increase in leverage increases Market Cap / Equity by approximately 1%.

Net margins exhibit a comparatively modest elasticity, suggesting that accounting profitability, while important, does not independently command valuation premiums.

Taken together, the results align closely with how long-term equity investors think: sustainable valuation expansion is rooted in efficient deployment of capital, not short-term margin optimization.

 

The key result: persistency dominates

The model has R2 of 94.05% and Adjusted R2 of 93.91%.  If we decompose the individual predictors‚Äô contribution to this explained variance in Market Cap/Equity, the key conclusion emerges:

Visually, this is striking: the largest block by far is leverage. Most of what investors paid for Home Depot over 35 years is captured by three variables of which Leverage is the most significant. This is what Goldman Sachs found in their panel data analysis calling the hedonic pricing element persistency.

Persistency, in Goldman‚Äôs framework, means:

  • Stable capital structure
  • Predictable balance-sheet scaling
  • Consistency in how equity is multiplied into assets and cash flows

What we have done here is replicate that insight, but:

  • For one company
  • Using 35 years of quarterly data
  • With a fully transparent regression framework

The alignment is almost exact.

Notably, the model contains no explicit time trends, macroeconomic variables, or sentiment indicators‚Äîyet it explains over 94% of valuation variation, underscoring how consistently markets price the same economic fundamentals.

In Home Depot‚Äôs case, leverage alone explains roughly two-thirds of the market‚Äôs valuation signal. Profitability matters ‚Äî but it is secondary, less persistent, and less trusted by investors as a long-term signal.

Both actual and predicted series represent the log market-cap-to-equity multiple where

The chart shows that a simple three-variable hedonic model tracks Home Depot‚Äôs valuation remarkably well over more than three decades. Even though the model has no awareness of time, cycles, or sentiment, its predicted valuation closely follows the actual market valuation across multiple regimes. Deviations between the two lines are concentrated in periods of market stress or speculative excess, while long-run trends are captured cleanly.

In other words, investors consistently price the same economic fundamentals, though they might temporarily lose discipline during panics and recessions.

This directly supports the executive intuition captured in the quote by Dilip Shanghvi, the founder and CEO of Sun Pharmaceuticals:

‚ÄúI will never risk capital; but I will risk profit.‚Äù

Markets agree.

 

3. How solid is our model? Is it "too clean"?

No serious business model should avoid this question.

Residual behavior (what we checked)

We explicitly reviewed:

  • Residual distribution
  • Residuals vs. fitted values
  • Time clustering during stress periods

 

 


 


 

With F-statistics 684.4 on 3 and 130 degrees of freedom and p-value < 2.2 x 10-16, the model is structurally sound, though markets still panic occasionally ‚Äî and then revert.

That is exactly what we would expect from real investors.

What do residuals tell us

Residuals widen during periods of macro-financial stress, including the Global Financial Crisis, COVID, and the post-2022 rate shock. This is expected: markets temporarily price fear, liquidity constraints, and narrative risk beyond firm-level fundamentals.

Outside stress regimes, residuals oscillate tightly around zero with no persistent bias. Deviations cluster in time rather than by sign, indicating regime effects rather than model misspecification. Overvaluation episodes‚Äîmost notably the late 1990s‚Äîmean-revert as market discipline reasserts itself.

Bottom line: the model ‚Äúfails‚Äù when markets panic ‚Äî and reliably re-anchors valuation once sentiment normalizes.

 

*   *   *

 

So, what does this actually mean for Home Depot?

Insight #1: capital discipline is the valuation anchor

Home Depot‚Äôs high valuation multiple is not fragile.  It is anchored in:

  • Consistent leverage
  • Predictable scaling of equity
  • Transparent capital return policy

Any unexpected shift in capital structure ‚Äî aggressive deleveraging or sudden debt expansion ‚Äî would matter far more to valuation than a bad margin quarter.

Insight #2: profitability matters ‚Äî but only if it is repeatable

Operational improvements (margin, turnover, ROA) explain about one quarter of valuation variation.  That is meaningful ‚Äî but markets discount one-off wins.  Investors prefer:

  • Incremental improvements
  • Predictable execution
  • Fewer surprises

Spectacular quarters impress analysts. Consistent ones move valuation.

Insight #3: macro matters less than headlines suggest

Despite constant focus on rates, housing cycles, and sentiment, macro variables explain only a single-digit share of long-term valuation variation.  Home Depot‚Äôs valuation history is fundamentally a company-driven story, not a macro-driven one.

Once full-year 2025 financials are available, we will:

  • Re-estimate the model
  • Test coefficient stability
  • Re-evaluate valuation implications under the new regime and compare/contrast the hedonic pricing model with the traditional DCF valuation model

If history is any guide, the conclusion is unlikely to change ‚Äî but the path may.

 

Final thought

Markets are often accused of being short-term and irrational. Over 35 years of Home Depot data suggests the opposite.

Investors are remarkably consistent in what they reward.

They pay for persistency.

entry.title: High Impact SAP Data Objects to Clean for an S/4HANA Selective Transition from ECC
entry.content:
*Views Expressed here are my own and doesn't represent any entity.

Introduction

Moving from SAP ECC to S/4HANA using a Selective Data Transition is not just a technical system conversion,it is a data transformation journey. While selective carve outs allow organizations to migrate only relevant organizational units, time slices, or data sets, poor data quality can jeopardize the entire S/4HANA transformation.S/4HANA‚Äôs simplified data model, stricter checks, and real-time processing mean that legacy inconsistencies tolerated in ECC will cause errors, functional gaps, or performance issues in S/4HANA.

This blog outlines the SAP data objects that require mandatory data cleaning before a selective S/4HANA migration, along with practical examples and rationale for each.

Why Data Cleaning Is Mandatory in a Selective Transition

In a selective approach:

  • Only chosen company codes, plants, or years are migrated

  • Historical inconsistencies become more visible

  • Data is restructured, not simply converted

S/4HANA:

  • Enforces business partner (BP) as a single master

  • Removes many legacy tables

  • Uses real-time reconciliation

  • Requires consistent master and transactional data

Without cleaning, you risk:

  • Migration failures

  • Reconciliation mismatches

  • Broken business processes

  • Delayed go-lives

1. Business Partner (Customer & Vendor)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Duplicate customers/vendors

  • Inconsistent master data across company codes

  • Missing mandatory fields (address, tax, bank details)

  • Vendors acting as customers (and vice versa)

ECC Example

  • Vendor 100045 exists for AP

  • Customer 200078 exists for AR

  • Same legal entity, different tax IDs and addresses

Why This Is Mandatory

In S/4HANA:

  • Customers and Vendors are merged into Business Partner

  • Roles (Customer, Supplier) are assigned to a single BP number

  • Inconsistent data causes CVI (Customer Vendor Integration) errors

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only certain company codes, making duplicates harder to reconcile post-migration. Cleaning ensures:

  • Smooth BP conversion

  • Accurate AR/AP reporting

  • Compliance with S/4 data model

2. Material Master Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Obsolete or unused materials

  • Incomplete views (MM, SD, PP)

  • Invalid units of measure

  • Duplicate material numbers

ECC Example

  • Material created but never used in 8 years

  • Sales view missing for materials with open SD history

  • Base UoM inconsistent with alternative UoM

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time MRP

  • Uses simplified inventory tables (MATDOC)

  • Enforces stricter checks on material consistency

Rationale

Migrating unused or inconsistent materials:

  • Increases migration volume

  • Slows performance

  • Causes MRP and ATP errors

Selective transitions benefit most by reducing material footprint.

3. Chart of Accounts & G/L Accounts

What Needs Cleaning

  • Blocked or unused G/L accounts

  • Accounts without proper account type

  • Inconsistent descriptions across company codes

  • Legacy reconciliation accounts

ECC Example

  • G/L 799999 created for testing, never used

  • Same G/L has different names in different company codes

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Introduces Universal Journal (ACDOCA)

  • FI and CO are merged

  • Reconciliation accounts behave differently

Rationale

Dirty G/L data leads to:

  • Conversion errors

  • Financial reconciliation issues

  • Incorrect financial statements

In selective transitions, only active and relevant accounts should be migrated.

4. Open Financial Transactions (AR/AP)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Cleared documents not properly closed

  • Open items with incorrect statuses

  • Residual items with zero balance

  • Old parked documents

ECC Example

  • Invoice marked as open but cleared manually

  • Zero-balance open items still flagged as open

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time reconciliation

  • No longer tolerates technical inconsistencies

  • Universal Journal requires exact balances

Rationale

Open AR/AP items are always migrated in selective scenarios. Incorrect open items cause:

  • Balance mismatches

  • Failed migrations

  • Post-go-live reconciliation chaos

5. Asset Accounting (FI-AA)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Assets without acquisition values

  • Assets without depreciation areas

  • Retired assets still marked as active

  • Incomplete asset master records

ECC Example

  • Asset created but never capitalized

  • Depreciation area missing for a company code

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses New Asset Accounting only

  • Fully integrated into Universal Journal

  • Legacy asset inconsistencies cannot be converted

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only active assets. Cleaning ensures:

  • Correct depreciation

  • Accurate asset balances

  • Compliance with S/4 FI-AA model

6. Open Logistics Transactions

What Needs Cleaning

  • Open purchase orders with no activity

  • Incomplete deliveries

  • Open production orders never closed

  • Inconsistent goods movements

ECC Example

  • PO created 6 years ago, no GR, no IR

  • Production order technically complete but not closed

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses MATDOC for inventory

  • Enforces strict document flow

  • Real-time stock valuation

Rationale

Open logistics documents are technically migrated, not recreated. Dirty data causes:

  • Stock inconsistencies

  • Migration failures

  • Incorrect inventory valuation

7. Customizing and Organizational Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Unused plants, storage locations

  • Inactive company codes

  • Invalid assignments (plant to company code)

  • Legacy controlling areas

ECC Example

  • Plant exists but no postings in 10 years

  • Company code included but not in scope

Why This Is Mandatory

Selective transitions rely on precise scoping. Invalid org data:

  • Complicates data slicing

  • Causes migration logic conflicts

  • Increases testing effort

Rationale

Clean org structures ensure:

  • Correct selective extraction

  • Lean S/4 system

  • Lower total cost of ownership

8. Custom Code & Z-Objects (Indirect Data Impact)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Z-tables with obsolete data

  • Custom programs using removed tables

  • Hard-coded company codes or years

ECC Example

  • Z-table referencing BKPF/BSEG directly

  • Custom report using VBFA incorrectly

Why This Is Mandatory

While not migrated as data:

  • Custom code processes migrated data

  • Dirty Z-data can break business processes

Rationale

Selective data migration often includes selective Z-data. Cleaning avoids:

  • Runtime errors

  • Incorrect reporting

  • Post-go-live defects

Understand your Business "WHY" for DATA CLEARLY

A Selective S/4HANA transition magnifies data quality issues because only parts of the system are migrated. S/4HANA‚Äôs simplified architecture does not tolerate inconsistencies that ECC allowed for decades.

Mandatory Data Cleaning Ensures:

  • Successful migration runs

  • Accurate financial reconciliation

  • Stable business processes

  • Long-term S/4HANA performance

Key Takeaway:

Data cleansing is not a technical task‚Äîit is a business transformation enabler.

#S4HANA #DATA #DATACLEANSING #MandatoryS4HANADATAOBJECTS #SAPECCtoS4HANA #SelectiveTransformation #DataQuality #ERPTransformation

#LegacyModernization
